children.value: Explore, navigate, and better understand all code, everywhere, faster with Sourcegraph Universal Code Search. Uber, Lyft, Yelp, and other enterprises rely on Sourcegraph to improve developer productivity and manage large-scale code changes.
📣 Campaigns beta available to all site admins
🔑 Faster syncing of GitHub repository permissions
🔎 Experimental AND/OR operators for search contents
👀 New visibility filter for scoping searches to public or private repositories
🏁 Getting started prompt contains more context
🧩 Extension and code intelligence UI improvements
⚙️ User event logs available in user settings
🍴 Setting to include forked and archived repositories
Every detail that changed in this release
Sourcegraph couldn’t be what it is without the community.
Go in-depth with the 3.15 release by watching the recorded livestream with Product Manager
: Sourcegraph site admins should definitely check out
Beyang discussing improvements to monitoring, observability, and alerting

hProperties.aria-label: Campaigns beta available to all site admins permalink

children.value: Campaigns beta available to all site admins
View on YouTube

Campaigns are available for general use in beta by any Sourcegraph instance admin. Users of Sourcegraph.com will need to run a private Sourcegraph instance with their repositories added to try running campaigns on their code. Sourcegraph admins can enable campaigns on their instance by adding
We are excited to hear about the campaigns you run, answer questions you have, and hear your feedback! Get in touch on Twitter
Campaigns are currently in beta. During the beta period, campaigns are free to use. After the beta period, campaigns will be available as a paid add-on. Please

hProperties.aria-label: Faster syncing of GitHub repository permissions permalink

children.value: Faster syncing of GitHub repository permissions
Sourcegraph 3.15 adds faster repository permissions syncing at scale for GitHub. This functionality was previously
introduced for GitLab and Bitbucket Server

in Sourcegraph 3.14. Rather than syncing a user’s permissions when they log in and potentially blocking them from seeing search results, Sourcegraph syncs these permissions asynchronously in the background, opportunistically refreshing them in a timely manner. See the

hProperties.aria-label: Experimental ANDOR operators for search contents permalink

children.value: Experimental AND/OR operators for search contents
View on YouTube
Search for file contents using AND and OR expressions in queries. These operators enable more expressive searches in regexp and structural search modes.
includes more details about how to these operators and their precedence and grouping.
For example, if you want to find all of the places where two functions are within the same file, you can use the AND operator:
Or, if you want to find everywhere two functions are used whether or not the other is present, you would use the OR operator:
You can even use them together:
Currently, operators only support searching file contents and do not apply to search scopes - you will see an alert if your query is not supported.
We continue to invest heavily in making Sourcegraph easier to monitor and debug out-of-the-box.
Sourcegraph now has pre-defined alerts for 93 metrics across 14 services for improved monitoring.
For now, these new alerts are warning-level alerts. In the future, they will be elevated to critical-level alerts when there is more confidence in their accuracy.
8 bug fixes to alerting and dashboards.
11 changes to improve the legibility and visibility of dashboards.
All dashboard panels now show an orange/red background when a metric is reaching its warning/critical threshold, making it easy to see which metrics are most interesting.
Search error rate and latency is now broken down by type on the frontend dashboard:
Search at a glance (browser web UI).
Search-based code intelligence at a glance.
Search API usage at a glance.

If you have previously configured alert thresholds on the frontend dashboard manually (instead of on the Grafana home dashboard as typically recommended), you will need to reconfigure those alert thresholds again after upgrading.

We’ve added a new tool to all Sourcegraph deployments by default: Distributed tracing. It is a powerful tool for investigating performance issues. You can enable tracing selectively per-request and capture detailed information about, for example, a search request which can then easily be inspected to find out what the slowest parts were within the inner-workings of Sourcegraph.
To use tracing, please see our
Additionally, it is now possible to log all search and GraphQL requests slower than N milliseconds, using the new site configuration options
. When Sourcegraph’s monitoring (or your instances’ users) inform you that queries are slow, this allows you to see the exact details of the search or GraphQL request needed to reproduce it.

hProperties.aria-label: New visibility filter for scoping searches to public or private repositories permalink

children.value: New visibility filter for scoping searches to public or private repositories
View on YouTube
search scope enables filtering based on a repository’s shared state on the code host. Scope options include any, public, or private, and defaults to
when the scope is not specified.

hProperties.aria-label: Getting started prompt contains more context permalink

children.value: Getting started prompt contains more context

When using Sourcegraph for the first time on a private instance, a getting started section is shown to help admins and users make sure their Sourcegraph instance is properly configured, and that they know how to perform a search. The getting started steps now include more context about how to complete each step.

hProperties.aria-label: Extension and code intelligence UI improvements permalink

children.value: Extension and code intelligence UI improvements
Even small things can have a large impact on user experience, and we are working on improving how users interact with Sourcegraph. For this release, we cleaned up the design of buttons contributed by
in the Sourcegraph webapp and on code host

. In addition, we reworked our logic for when we display loading indicators in hover tooltips that sometimes caused tooltips to not show up reliably. These changes provide a more consistent experience with visual elements and component interactions.

hProperties.aria-label: User event logs available in user settings permalink

children.value: User event logs available in user settings

Users and site administrators can now view a log of their actions/events in user settings. This enables site admins to perform rough audits of users and also helps users better understand the information Sourcegraph logs.

has been added to provide results with a deterministic search result order. This search scope only applies to file contents and is limited to 5,000 maximum results. You should consider using the paginated search API if you need more than 5,000 results.

hProperties.aria-label: Setting to include forked and archived repositories permalink

children.value: Setting to include forked and archived repositories

Sourcegraph 3.14 removed archived and forked repositories from search results by default. While this was an improvement to most users, some organizations have a configuration that necessitates searching these repositories. Sourcegraph 3.15 enables those organizations to add a global setting to their instance to always include forks or archived repositories in searches. Enable this in global, organization, or user settings with

Observability (debugging): It is now possible to log all search and GraphQL requests slower than N milliseconds, using the new site configuration options
More metrics monitored and alerted on, more legible dashboards
Dashboard panels now show an orange/red background color when the defined warning/critical alert threshold has been met, making it even easier to see what is in a bad state on a dashboard.
Frontend dashboard: Search error types are now broken into distinct panels for improved visibility/legibility.
: If you have previously configured alerting on any of these panels or on “hard search errors”, you will need to reconfigure it after upgrading.
Frontend dashboard: Search error and latency are now broken down by type: Browser requests, search-based code intel requests, and API requests.
Distributed tracing is a powerful tool for investigating performance issues.
The following changes have been made with the goal of making it easier to use distributed tracing with Sourcegraph:
allows a site admin to control which requests generate tracing data.
(recommended) will trace all requests initiated from an end-user URL with
. Non-end-user-initiated requests can set a HTTP header
. This is the recommended setting, as
can generate large amounts of tracing data that may cause network and memory resource contention in the Sourcegraph instance.

Jaeger is now the officially supported distributed tracing system. The following is the recommended site configuration to connect Sourcegraph to a Jaeger agent (which must be deployed on the same host and listening on the default ports):

Jaeger is now included in the Sourcegraph deployment configuration by default if you are using Kubernetes, Docker Compose, or the pure Docker cluster deployment model. It is not yet included in the single Docker container distribution. Jaeger will be included as part of upgrading to 3.15 in these deployment models, unless disabled.

Support for configuring Lightstep as a distributed tracer is deprecated and will be removed in a subsequent release. Instances that use Lightstep with Sourcegraph are encouraged to migrate to Jaeger (directions for running Jaeger alongside Sourcegraph are included in the installation instructions).
Multiple backwards-incompatible changes in the parts of the GraphQL API related to Campaigns
has been removed, since we don’t need it anymore after moving execution of campaigns to src CLI in
Removed the scoped search field on tree pages. When browsing code, the global search query will now get scoped to the current tree or file.
Instances without a license key that exceed the published user limit will now display a notice to all users.
in the filter pattern were ignored and led to missing search results.
The Phabricator integration no longer makes duplicate requests to Phabricator’s API on diff views.
Changesets on repositories that aren’t available on the instance anymore are now hidden instead of failing.
Syntect Server dashboard: “Worker timeouts” can no longer appear to go negative.
Symbols dashboard: “Store fetch queue size” can no longer appear to go negative.
Syntect Server dashboard: “Worker timeouts” no longer incorrectly shows multiple values.
Searcher dashboard: “Search errors on unindexed repositories” no longer includes cancelled search requests (which are expected).
Fixed an issue where NaN could leak into the
duration_slow” alert is no longer flaky/non-deterministic.
Git Server dashboard: There is now a panel to show concurrent command executions to match the defined alerts.
Git Server dashboard: Adjusted the critical disk space alert to 15% so it can now fire.
All: “frontend internal errors” are now broken down just by route, which makes reading the graph easier.
Frontend dashboard: Panels no longer show misleading duplicate labels.
Syntect Server dashboard: Panels are no longer compacted, for improved visibility.
Frontend dashboard: Panels are no longer compacted, for improved visibility.
Searcher dashboard: “Search errors on unindexed repositories” is now broken down by code instead of instance for improved readability.
Symbols dashboard: Metrics are now aggregated instead of per-instance, for improved visibility.
Firing alerts are now correctly sorted at the top of dashboards by default.
Panels at the bottom of the home dashboard no longer appear clipped/cut off.
Git Server dashboard: Disk usage now shown in percentages to match the alerts that can fire.
Git Server dashboard: The ‘echo command duration test’ panel now properly displays units in seconds.
Dashboard panels showing firing alerts no longer over-count firing alerts due to the number of service replicas.
changelog for this and previous releases
Thank you to the many people who contributed to Sourcegraph since the last release!
